According to the 2012 Harkin Report and the NY Times, students at for-profit colleges made up "13 percent of the nation's college enrollment, but account for about 47 percent of the defaults on loans. About 96 percent of students at for-profit schools take out loans, compared with about 13 percent at community colleges and 48 percent at four-year public universities."<ref name="nytimes2">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/30/education/harkin-report-condemns-for-profit-colleges.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|publisher=nytimes.com|title=Harkin Report Condemns For-Profit Colleges - The New York Times |accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref><ref name="help.senate.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.help.senate.gov/imo/media/for_profit_report/PartI-PartIII-SelectedAppendixes.pdf |format=PDF |title=For Profit Higher Education: The Failure to Safeguard the Federal Investment and Ensure Student Success |publisher=Help.senate.gov |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> In October 2017, Strayer and Capella agreed to merge as Strategic Education,<ref name="insidehighered.com1"/> officially completing the merger in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/capella-and-strayer-complete-1-2-billion-merger-take-new-name-as-strategic-education/489752481/|title=Capella and Strayer complete merger, shares soar nearly 12 percent on strong Q2 results}}</ref>
A 2014 report by The Institute for College Access and Success showed that the likelihood of a student defaulting was three times more likely at a for-profit college than a 4-year public or non-profit college and almost four times more likely than a community college.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://ticas.org/content/pub/despite-lower-rates-more-650000-defaulted-federal-student-loans-0 |title=Despite Lower Rates, More Than 650,000 Defaulted on Federal Student Loans | The Institute For College Access and Success |publisher=Ticas.org |date=2014-09-24 |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
According to data provided by colleges and universities to the [[National Center for Education Statistics]], enrollment in for-profit institutions declined 21% between 2010 and 2013.<ref name="bizjournals">{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/albuquerque/news/2016/04/15/for-profit-academic-institutions-like-university.html?ana=yahoo|publisher=bizjournals.com|title=www.bizjournals.com/albuquerque/news/2016/04/15/for-profit-academic-institutions-like-university.html?ana=yahoo|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> Student enrollment declined an additional 10% from 2014 to 2015.<ref name="counterpunch">{{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2016/09/05/the-itt-fraud-for-profit-education-and-the-crisis-of-the-commons/|publisher=counterpunch.org|title=The ITT Fraud: For-Profit Education and the Crisis of the Commons|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> More than 200 for-profit college campuses and learning sites have closed since 2012, including more than 100 [[University of Phoenix]] campuses<ref name="nytimes3">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/18/education/university-of-phoenix-to-close-115-locations.html?_r=0|publisher=nytimes.com|title=University of Phoenix to Close 115 Locations - The New York Times|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> and most Everest College campuses.<ref name="wbaltv">{{cite web|url=http://www.wbaltv.com/education/everest-college-campuses-closing-in-11-states/26887840|publisher=wbaltv.com|title=Everest College campuses closing in 11 states|date=2014-07-10|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref>
In 2015, [[Corinthian Colleges]] filed for bankruptcy and all of its [[Heald College]] campuses were closed.<ref name="latimes2">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-corinthian-shutdown-20150427-story.html|publisher=latimes.com|title=Corinthian closing its last schools; 10,000 California students displaced - LA Times|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> In 2016, all [[Westwood College]] campuses were closed.<ref name="insidehighered.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/quicktakes/2016/01/29/profit-westwood-college-announces-closing|publisher=insidehighered.com|title=For-Profit Westwood College Announces Closing|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> [[Le Cordon Bleu]] was also in the process of closing all of its campuses.<ref name="insidehighered2">{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/quicktakes/2015/12/17/career-ed-closing-down-le-cordon-bleu-operations|publisher=insidehighered.com|title=Career Ed Closing Down Le Cordon Bleu Operations|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> [[ITT Technical Institute]]<ref name="insidehighered3">{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/quicktakes/2015/10/19/itt-tech-suspends-enrollment-several-campuses|publisher=insidehighered.com|title=ITT Tech Suspends Enrollment at Several Campuses|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> and [[Devry]]<ref name="chicagotribune">{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-devry-closings-0425-biz-20150424-story.html|publisher=chicagotribune.com|title=DeVry to close some out-of-state campuses - Chicago Tribune|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> also closed multiple campuses.
In 2016, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that more than 180 for-profit college campuses had closed between 2014 and 2016.<ref name="wsj">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/obama-empties-innovative-classrooms-1466635226|work=The Wall Street Journal|author=Finley, Alyssa|title=Obama Empties Innovative Classrooms|date=June 22, 2016|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20160625094259/http://www.wsj.com/articles/obama-empties-innovative-classrooms-1466635226|archivedate=June 25, 2016|accessdate=February 18, 2017}}</ref> For-profit college enrollment dropped about 15% in 2016, a 165,000 decline.<ref name="hechingerreport2">{{cite web|url=http://hechingerreport.org/college-university-enrollment-fifth-straight-year/|publisher=hechingerreport.org|title=College and university enrollment is down for fifth straight year - The Hechinger Report|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> Enrollment at University of Phoenix chain fell 22%, which was a 70% loss since 2010. [[DeVry University]] reported a 23% percent in 2016. Hondros College, a nursing school chain, dropped 14%.<ref name="chicagotribune2">{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-for-profit-colleges-enrollment-slide-20160922-story.html|publisher=chicagotribune.com|title=Amid scrutiny, for-profit colleges see enrollment slide - Chicago Tribune|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> In June 2016, Education Management announced that it was planning to close all 25 [[Brown Mackie College]] campuses. In September 2016, [[ITT Technical Institute]] closed all of its campuses. In September 2016, the [[US Department of Education]] stripped [[ACICS]] of its accreditation powers.
In 2017, all Cordon Bleu schools are expected to close.<ref name="sec2">{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1046568/000156459016027351/ceco-10q_20160930.htm|publisher=sec.gov|title=ceco-10q_20160930.htm|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> At least 19 Art Institutes are also expected to close.<ref name="wtae">{{cite web|url=http://www.wtae.com/article/many-art-institute-employees-laid-off-in-pittsburgh/7479864|publisher=wtae.com|title=Many Art Institute employees laid off in Pittsburgh|date=2016-05-05|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> Education Management Corporation sold its remaining schools to the non-profit Dream Foundation and [[Purdue University]] proposed purchasing Kaplan University.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mollyhensleyclancy/for-1-purdue-university-will-acquire-a-massive-for-profit|title=Here's Why Purdue University Is Buying A Massive For-Profit College For $1|website=Buzzfeed.com|access-date=January 1, 2018}}</ref> Atalem also sold its declining DeVry University and the Keller School of Management to Cogswell Education, a division of Palm Ventures.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mollyhensleyclancy/devry-university-will-be-sold-to-a-tiny-college-company|title=Troubled DeVry University Gets Sold Off For A Pittance|first=Molly|last=Hensley-Clancy|website=BuzzFeed|access-date=January 1, 2018}}</ref>
In 2018, the documentary Fail State chronicled the boom and bust of for-profit colleges, highlighting the abuses that led to their downfall.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.texasobserver.org/fail-state-delves-shadowy-world-profit-colleges/|title=‘Fail State’ Delves into the Shadowy World of For-Profit Colleges|author=|date=October 27, 2017|website=texasobserver.org}}</ref>
On August 10, 2018, US Education Secretary Betsy Devos scrapped a rule issued by the US Department of Education in 2010 which would have forced for-profit colleges to prove that the students they enroll are able to attain "gainful employment."<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2018/08/10/trumps-education-department-moves-to-rescind-rule-aimed-at-for-profit-schools/</ref><ref name=july2019>https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/10/us/politics/betsy-devos-for-profit-colleges.html</ref><ref>https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/10/politics/devos-obama-for-profit-college-rule/index.html</ref> The gainful employment policy will expire on July 1, 2019.<ref name=july2019 /><ref>https://www.10news.com/newsy/betsy-devos-wants-to-end-rules-meant-to-curb-abuse-by-some-colleges</ref> In the 30-day period before its expiration, however, the Department of Education will gather public input.<ref>https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/devos-proposes-rollback-of-for-profit-college-rule</ref>
In September 2018, [[Education Corporation of America]] announced that they would be closing 26 campuses, which included several [[Virginia College]] campuses.<ref>https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2018/09/12/profit-chain-will-close-dozens-campuses</ref>
In November 2018, the US Department of Education restored [[Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools]] (ACICS) as a higher education accreditor. The organization had lost its authority during the Obama administration. <ref>https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2018/11/26/devos-restores-authority-profit-accreditor</ref>
==Structure of for-profit education==
===Sources of capital and cash flow=== The main sources of initial capital for public for-profit colleges are institutional investors: international banks, hedge funds, institutional retirement funds, and state retirement funds.<ref name="huffingtonpost"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2014/07/11/goldman-sachs-kkr-flunk-in-college-investment/|title=Goldman Sachs, KKR flunk in college investment|work=New York Post|accessdate=14 June 2015|first=Josh|last=Kosman|date=12 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E9KJWnyDk1sC&pg=PA53&lpg=PA53&dq=warburg+pincus+acquires+bridgepoint+education&source=bl&ots=up1k-FrajK&sig=XH6RJm6-Zn644BClpMJiLEQ1kkQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QxO5VLrlMIXjsASL3YDYDQ&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=warburg%20pincus%20acquires%20bridgepoint%20education&f=false|title=Corporations Are Not People|publisher=Books.google.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
[[Wells Fargo]] was a major funder of [[Corinthian Colleges]]<ref name="huffingtonpost2">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/davidhalperin/who-owns-the-awful-corint_b_4101323.html|publisher=huffingtonpost.com|title=Who Owns The Awful Corinthian Colleges? Wells Fargo, Marc Morial, Pension Funds | The Huffington Post|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> and [[Goldman Sachs]] provided a significant amount of capital to [[Education Management Corporation]].<ref name="edmc">{{cite web|url=http://www.edmc.edu/About/History.aspx|publisher=edmc.edu|title=Education Management Corporation - History|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref>
The main source of cash flow consists of US Department of Education [[Higher Education Act of 1965|Higher Education Act]] [[Title IV]] funds. Title IV funds include Federal Family Education Loans (FFEL), direct loans, Federal Perkins Loans, Federal [[Pell Grants]], Academic Competitiveness Grants (ACG), National SMART Grants, Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants (FSEOG), and Federal Work-Study (FWS).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://federalstudentaid.ed.gov/site/front2back/programs/programs/fb_03_01_0030.htm|title=What are Title IV Programs?|publisher=Federalstudentaid.ed.gov|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> In the 1990s, Congress began requiring that for-profit schools receive at least 10% of their revenues from non-federal student aid sources, which include the GI Bill.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bair|first1=Sheila|authorlink1=Sheila Bair|title=For-Profit Schools Are a Bad Deal for Both Investors and Taxpayers |journal=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=January 1, 2015|volume=171|issue=1|page=39}}</ref>
In the 2009–2010 academic year, for-profit higher education corporations received $32 billion in [[Title IV]] funding—more than 20% of all federal aid.<ref name="scholarship.law.duke.edu"/> For-profit colleges get approximately 70% of their funds from Title IV programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/files/pub/90-10_Q_and_A_Oct_2013_Update.pdf |title=Search |publisher=Projectonstudentdebt.org|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> However, some colleges get more than 80% of their funds from Title IV.<ref name="help.senate.gov"/>
The for-profit education industry also receives billions of dollars through VA benefits also known as the [[GI Bill]].<ref name="help.senate.gov" /> In the 2010–2011 school year, more than $1 billion went to eight for-profit schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/article/8-For-Profit-Colleges-Collect/129124/|title=8 For-Profit Colleges Collect More Than $1-Billion in Veterans' Education Benefits|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/article/For-Profit-Colleges-Still-Cash/147977/|title=For-Profit Colleges Still Cash In on Post-9/11 GI Bill, Harkin Report Says|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> In the 2012–2013 academic year, 31 percent of GI Bill funds went to for-profit colleges. Veteran participation in these schools, in effect, transferred $1.7 billion in post-9/11 GI Bill funds to these schools.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zillman|first1=Claire|title=Obama's budget aims to eliminate for-profit colleges' GI Bill loophole|journal=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=February 3, 2015|url=http://fortune.com/2015/02/03/gi-bill-for-profit-colleges-2/|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
These corporations also obtain cash flow through student private loans, corporate loans, and the selling of assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CPRT-112SPRT74931/pdf/CPRT-112SPRT74931.pdf |format=PDF |title=For Profit Higher Education: The Failure to Safeguard the Federal Investment and Ensure Student Success |publisher=Gpo.gov |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/new-report-shows-nearly-2-billion-of-gi-bill-funds-go-to-for-profit-colleges/|title=New report shows nearly $2 billion in GI Bill funds go to for-profit colleges|work=PBS NewsHour|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> Problems with high-interest private loans to students at [[Corinthian Colleges]] (Genesis loans) and [[ITT Tech]] (PEAKS and CUSO loans) have gained scrutiny from the [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]] and the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.consumerfinance.gov/newsroom/cfpb-sues-for-profit-corinthian-colleges-for-predatory-lending-scheme/|title=CFPB Sues For-Profit Corinthian Colleges for Predatory Lending Scheme|publisher=Consumer Financial Protection Bureau|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/itt-educational-sinks-disclosing-sec-164532930.html|title=ITT Educational sinks after disclosing SEC probe|date=25 February 2013|work=Yahoo Finance|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
==Benefits== Historically, for-profit education has offered open admissions to non-traditional students, convenience of schedule and location, instructors with workplace knowledge, and real world vocational training rather than traditional training. Critics of [[Wall Street]]-backed for-profit educators, however, have questioned these perceived benefits.<ref name="huffingtonpost.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nacacnet.org/issues-action/LegislativeNews/Pages/For-Profit-Colleges.aspx|title=The Low-Down on For-Profit Colleges|publisher=Nacacnet.org|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2014/01/for-profit-college-student-debt|title=Screw U: How For-Profit Colleges Rip You Off|work=Mother Jones|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
For-profit schools like [[University of Phoenix]] are said to be more inclusive, recruiting and graduating more African Americans than public higher education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/tomorrows-college/phoenix/who-goes-to-university-of-phoenix.html|title=Who Goes to the University of Phoenix?|author=American Public Media|publisher=Americanradioworks.publicradio.org|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://urbanmecca.net/news/2008/12/06/more-minority-students-earn-degrees-from-university-of-phoenix/|title=More Minority Students Earn Degrees From University of Phoenix|work=Urbanmecca.com - African American News|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education has called University of Phoenix "a pillar of African American higher education."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbhe.com/2012/02/the-university-of-phoenix-is-a-pillar-of-african-american-higher-education/|title=The University of Phoenix Is a Pillar of African American Higher Education|work=The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> Through the Thurgood Marshall fund, students at 47 publicly supported [[historically Black colleges and universities]], may supplement their on-campus course loads with course programs using the University of Phoenix online platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbhe.com/2014/11/university-of-phoenix-signs-agreement-to-offer-online-courses-to-hbcu-students/#comments|title=University of Phoenix Signs Agreement to Offer Online Courses to HBCU Students|work=The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
For-profit colleges have also been seen as a second chance for students who have performed poorly in the past.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eric.ed.gov/?id=EJ989048|title=ERIC - Choice of For-Profit College, Economics of Education Review, 2012-Dec|publisher=Eric.ed.gov|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
It may be argued that for-profit colleges also created innovations that would force public higher education to be more responsive to student needs<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecs.org/html/Document.asp?chouseid=1815 |title=Profit-Making or Profiteering? Proprietaries Target Teacher Education |publisher=Ecs.org |date= |accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref>
For-profit colleges have been compared favorably to [[community colleges]] in regards to graduation rates,<ref name="stripes.com"/> but these comparisons may be offering misleading statistical comparisons<ref name="mediamatters.org">{{cite web|url=http://mediamatters.org/research/2015/01/12/wsj-uses-bad-numbers-to-wipe-away-downside-of-f/202104 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150116122736/http://mediamatters.org/research/2015/01/12/wsj-uses-bad-numbers-to-wipe-away-downside-of-f/202104 |archivedate=16 January 2015 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icl-fi.org/english/wv/1052/ysp-education.html|title=Wall Street's For-Profit University Rip-Off|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Icl-fi.org|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
==Drawbacks==
A 2010 report by the [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) documented misleading sales and marketing tactics used by several for-profits.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/04/education/04education.html?ref=tamarlewin|work=The New York Times|first=Tamar|last=Lewin|title=For-Profit Colleges Mislead Students, Report Finds|date=2010-08-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/09/education/09gao.html?ref=education|work=New York Times|first=Tamar|last=Lewin|title=U.S. Revises Report on Recruiting at For-Profit Colleges|date=2010-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://eric.ed.gov/PDFS/ED511120.pdf |format=PDF |title=FOR-PROFIT COLLEGES Undercover Testing Finds Colleges Encouraged Fraud and Engaged in Deceptive and Questionable Marketing Practices |publisher=Eric.ed.gov |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> Critics have also pointed out that more than half of for-profits' revenues are either spent on marketing or extracted as profits, with less than half spent on instruction.<ref name=Harkin>{{cite web|title=For-Profit College Investigation|url=http://www.harkin.senate.gov/help/forprofitcolleges.cfm|publisher=U.S. Senate|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Where Are Federal G.I. Bill Dollars Going?|url=http://www.harkin.senate.gov/documents/pdf/4eb2c45d86297.pdf|publisher=U.S. Senate|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Senator Harkin's Findings Regarding Veterans and For‐Profit Colleges|url=http://www.harkin.senate.gov/documents/pdf/4f9ac62292704.pdf|publisher=U.S. Senate|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref>
A 2011 study by the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]], in Cambridge, Massachusetts, reported that students who attend for-profit education institutions are more likely to be unemployed, earn less, have higher debt levels, and are more likely to default on their student loans than similar students at non-profit educational institutions.<ref name=Goldin>David J. Deming, Claudia Goldin, and Lawrence F. Katz, "[http://big.assets.huffingtonpost.com/forprofitpaper.pdf The For-Profit Postsecondary School Sector: Nimble Critters or Agile Predators?]" National Bureau of Economic Research 2011.</ref> Although for-profits typically serve students who are poorer or more likely to be minorities, these differences do not explain the differences in employment, income, debt levels, and student loan defaults.<ref name=Goldin/> The [[Government Accountability Office]] has also found that graduates of for-profits are less likely to pass licensing exams, and that poor student performance cannot be explained by different student demographics.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kelly Field|title= Demographics Do Not Explain For-Profit Colleges' Shortcomings on Student-Success Measures, GAO Says|journal=Chronicle of Higher Education|date=December 7, 2011|url=http://chronicle.com/article/article-content/130040/|publisher=Chronicle.com|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
A 2011 investigation by ''[[The New York Times]]'' suggested that for-profit higher education institutions typically have much higher [[student loan default]] rates than non-profits.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tamar Lewin|title=Student Loan Default Rates Rise Sharply in Past Year|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 12, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/13/education/13loans.html|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> Two documentaries by ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' have focused on alleged abuses in for profit higher education.<ref>{{cite AV media |people=[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]] |year=2010 |title=College, Inc. |medium=Television production |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/collegeinc/ |accessdate=15 July 2013 |publisher=[[PBS]] Distribution |isbn=9781608832835 |oclc=643117456}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/educating-sergeant-pantzke/ |title=Educating Sergeant Pantzke - Video | FRONTLINE |publisher=Pbs.org |date= |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
Compared to community colleges, some for-profits may have higher completion rates for certificates and associate degree programs,<ref name="mediamatters.org"/> but higher drop out rates for four-year bachelor's degrees.<ref name=Goldin/> However, studies suggest that one- and two-year programs often may not provide much economic benefit to students because the boost to wages is offset by increased debt. By contrast, four-year programs provide a large economic benefit.<ref name=Simkovic>Michael Simkovic, [http://ssrn.com/abstract=1941070 Risk-Based Student Loans] (2012)</ref>
For-profits have been sued for allegedly using aggressive and deceptive sales and marketing practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/education/college-inc/lawsuits-address-recruitment-practices-at-for-profit-colleges/|title=Lawsuits Address Recruitment Practices at For-Profit Colleges|work=FRONTLINE|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> Holly Petraeus, a high-ranking official at the [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]], has accused for-profits of preying on vulnerable military personnel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Hollister K. Petraeus|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/22/opinion/for-profit-colleges-vulnerable-gis.html|title= For-Profit Colleges, Vulnerable G.I.'s|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 September 2011|accessdate=4 July 2014}}</ref> Petraeus wrote:
:"This gives for-profit colleges an incentive to see service members as nothing more than dollar signs in uniform, and to use aggressive marketing to draw them in and take out private loans...One of the most egregious reports of questionable marketing involved a college recruiter who visited a Marine barracks at [[Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune|Camp Lejeune]], North Carolina. As the PBS program ''Frontline'' reported, the recruiter signed up Marines with serious brain injuries. The fact that some of them couldn’t remember what courses they were taking was immaterial, as long as they signed on the dotted line."
Opponents say that the fundamental purpose of an educational institution should be to educate, not to turn a profit. In 2000, Bob Chase, president of the [[National Education Association]], stated that "educating children is very different from producing a product".<ref name="BusinessWeek">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/2000/00_06/b3667001.htm|title=For-Profit Schools|accessdate=26 September 2008|author=William C Symonds|date=2000-02-07|work=BusinessWeek|publisher=The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc.}}</ref>
Certain postsecondary education programs at institutions of higher education are eligible for participation in the federal student aid programs, known as [[Title IV]] of the US [[Higher Education Act of 1965|Higher Education Act]] (HEA). These programs, which are offered by public and private not-for-profit institutions, postsecondary vocational institutions, and by for-profit proprietary institutions, should prepare students for [[gainful employment]]. For decades, the [[U.S. Department of Education]] (ED) had not established regulations that explicitly outlined what it means for a program to be properly preparing students for gainful employment. As pressing concerns about the quality of programs at for- profit institutions began to arise, the concerns about the level of student loan debt assumed by students did as well. Such issues led to new initiatives and rules to be set in place outlining the parameters for what should be mandated to help ensure gainful employment.
The 2011 Senate HELP committee released data showing one in every four students who enroll at a for-profit school default on their loans within three years of leaving, with for-profit students accounting for almost half of all loan defaults.<ref name="Sessions, Jennifer 2011">Sessions, Jennifer. (February 8, 2011). "Harkin Calls on For-Profit Colleges to End Deceptive Recruiting Practices". Senate HELP Committee. Accessed 4 February 2013.</ref> Most for-profit colleges charge enrollees much higher tuition rates than analogous programs at community colleges and state public universities despite credits being likely not eligible to be transferred to other institutions.<ref name="Sessions, Jennifer 2011"/> In fact, 96% of students attending for-profit college apply for federal student loans compared to 13% at community colleges. During the 2009–2010 school years, for-profit colleges received almost $32 billion in grants and loans provided to students under federal student aid programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gao.gov/products/GAO-12-150 |title=U.S. GAO - For-Profit Schools: Experiences of Undercover Students Enrolled in Online Classes at Selected Colleges |publisher=Gao.gov |date= |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> This staggering number means nearly all students at for-profit institutions acquire student loan debt, even when they do not earn the end product of a degree or accumulate increased earning power through their studies (Sessions, 2011). These statistics represent a large portion of for- profits, uncovering the serious need for greater accountability in ensuring students are making sound investments in such institutions.
According to the [[Government Accountability Office]], enrollment in such institutions has increased faster than traditional higher-education institutions in recent years. With the student and federal interest in such programs growing, so has the concern with their productivity. Regrettably, this is not a simple matter to address, as the issue is multidimensional. For-profit institutions have become an increasingly visible portion of the U.S. higher education sector. For-profits also acquire the largest percentage of their overall revenue from federal student aid programs, highlighting tax dollars are potentially not being used efficiently.<ref>Deming, David. (February, 2012). "The For-Profit Postsecondary School Sector: Nimble Critters or Agile Predators?" Center for Analysis Postsecondary education and employment.</ref>
Federal regulatory actions by the ED have attempted to address these issues in the Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended. These efforts were very contentious. For-profit institutions argue their sector is unfairly targeted and believe the Department of Education over stepped its boundaries in 2010 by implementing regulations specifying requirements for [[Gainful Employment]]. These rules outlined in a report by Congressional Research Service (CRS), aimed to hold for-profits accountable by creating standards which must be upheld and followed, which will in turn attempt create more opportunity for gainful employment amongst enrollees.<ref name="SmoleDavid">Smole, David. (January 23, 2013). "Department of Education Final Rules for Postsecondary Education Programs That Prepare Students for Gainful Employment in a Recognized Occupation". Accessed February 4, 2013. Congressional Research Service Database.</ref> Through these regulations the ED believed that institutions will reinforce their educational programs to meet these higher standards, and relatively few programs will fail. Programs that offer a rewarding education at a reasonable price will succeed, and institutions will continue to innovate to assist students and taxpayers.<ref>Federal Registrar. 76 FR 34385. "Program Integrity: Gainful Employment-Debt Measures". Accessed 2 February 2013.</ref>
The regulations mandated by the ED were to help regulate the for-profit sector and to combat the issue of gainful employment. However, the [[Association of Private Sector Colleges and Universities]], which endorses for –profits, challenged these regulations in court. On June 30, 2012 the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia decided to vacate most aspects of the regulations.<ref name="SmoleDavid" /> The court sustained that the ED had the authority to regulate gainful employment, yet it cited the ED had not provided rationale metrics or measures in the debt measures. At present, only the disclosure requirements of providing prospective students with placements rates, on time graduation rates and other similar information remain.<ref>Smole, David. (January 23, 2013). "Department of Education Final Rules for Postsecondary Education Programs That Prepare Students for Gainful Employment in a Recognized Occupation". Accessed February 4, 2013. Congressional Research Service Database</ref> On March 19, 2013 the judge ruled again in response to the ED's motion to reinstate the reporting requirements in order that it could implement the disclosure requirements of Gainful Employment. The judged denied the motion of the ED on the basis that the reporting requirements would violate the federal ban on the student unit record system. It is strongly debatable that the court's ruling negates the small amount of transparency and accountability mandated by the disclosure requirements, leaving the policy issue of for-profits being accountable for [[Gainful Employment]] unattended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newamerica.net/taxonomy/term/1764 |title=Welcome to nginx! |publisher=Newamerica.net |date= |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
Some former students claim that for-profit colleges make them feel like they went to the flea market and bought themselves a degree.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=6838088n CBS News Video, "For-Profit Colleges Under Fire"], September 18, 2010.</ref>
According to James G. Andrews of the [[American Association of University Professors]], corporate models of education harm the mission of education.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andrews |first=James G. |url=http://www.aaup.org/AAUP/pubsres/academe/2006/MJ/feat/andr.htm |title=How We Can Resist Corporatization |publisher=AAUP |date= |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222235655/http://www.aaup.org/AAUP/pubsres/academe/2006/MJ/feat/andr.htm |archivedate=22 December 2010 }}</ref>
Some critics have called for-profit education "subprime education", in an analogy with the [[subprime mortgage]]s bubble at the heart of the [[Great Recession]] – finding uninformed borrowers and loading them with debt they cannot afford, then securitizing and passing the loan onto third-party investors. Activist short seller [[Steve Eisman]] (famous for being a character in [[Michael Lewis]]'s ''[[The Big Short]]'') has described the accreditation situation regarding for-profits like ITT as follows: "The scandal here is exactly akin to the rating agency role in subprime securitizations."<ref>[https://www.cnbc.com/id/37896158/Greenberg_For_Profit_Schools_Subprime_Redux Greenberg: For-Profit Schools ... Subprime Redux?] Herb Greenberg, 24 Jun 2010</ref>
A two-year congressional investigation report—from a committee chaired by Senator [[Tom Harkin]], D-Iowa—examined enrollment numbers in selected for-profit higher education institutions. The committee found that $32 billion in federal funds were spent in 2009–2010 on for-profit colleges. The majority of students enrolled in the institutions left without a degree and carried post-schooling debt. Regarding the dropout rates, the report said 54% of students in bachelor's degree programs dropped out before degree completion and 63% of students in associate degree programs dropped out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.help.senate.gov/imo/media/for_profit_report/Contents.pdf|title=''For Profit Higher Education: The Failure to Safeguard the Federal Investment and Ensure Student Success''|website=Senate.gov|access-date=January 1, 2018}}</ref>
==Accreditation and transfer-of-credits== Many for-profit institutions of [[higher education]] have [[Regional accreditation#Regional accreditation vs. national accreditation|national accreditation]] rather than [[regional accreditation]]. Regionally accredited schools are predominantly academically oriented, non-profit institutions.<ref name="usaed"/><ref name=yahoo/> Nationally accredited schools are predominantly for-profit and offer vocational, career, or technical programs.<ref name="usaed"/><ref name="yahoo"/> Most regionally accredited schools will not accept transfer credits earned at a nationally accredited school because, except for some specialized areas such as nursing, the standards for regional accreditation are higher than those for national accreditation.<ref name="usaed">{{cite web|url=http://www.useducation.com.pk/stpages/typesofaccreditation.html |title=''Types of Accreditation'', Education USA website |publisher=Useducation.com.pk |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424074806/http://www.useducation.com.pk/stpages/typesofaccreditation.html |archivedate=24 April 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="yahoo">{{cite web|url=http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/education/courses/distancelearn-09.html |title=''What is the Difference Between Regional and National Accreditation'', Yahoo! Education website |publisher=Help.yahoo.com |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205210641/http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/education/courses/distancelearn-09.html |archivedate=5 December 2010 }}</ref><ref name="demand">{{cite web|author=Scott Jaschik|date=October 19, 2005|title=Demanding Credit|work=Insidehighered.com|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2005/10/19/transfer|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="tussle">{{cite web|author=Doug Lederman|url=http://insidehighered.com/news/2007/02/26/transfer|title=Tussling Over Transfer of Credit|work=Insidehighered.com|date=February 26, 2007|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
In the 2005 congressional discussions concerning reauthorization of the Higher Education Act and in the [[U.S. Secretary of Education]]'s [http://www.ed.gov/about/bdscomm/list/hiedfuture/index.html ''Commission on the Future of Higher Education''], there were proposals, ultimately unsuccessful, to mandate that regional accrediting agencies bar the schools they accredit from basing decisions on whether or not to accept credits for transfer ''solely'' on the accreditation of the "sending" school.<ref name=demand/><ref name=tussle/> They could still reject the credits, but they would have to have additional reasons.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} The American Commission of Career Schools and Colleges (ACCSC), a nonprofit accreditor for-profit schools, supported the proposed rule.<ref name=demand/><ref name=tussle/><ref name=agenda/> The ACCSC claims regionally accredited schools will not accept nationally accredited schools credits for purely arbitrary, prejudicial and/or anti-competitive reasons.<ref name=agenda/> It further stated that, since the Department of Education recognizes both national and regional accreditation, there is no reason for regionals to differentiate between the two and to do so amounts to an unwarranted denial of access.<ref name=demand/><ref name=tussle/><ref name="agenda">{{cite web|url=http://www.accsc.org/Student-Corner/Transfer-of-Credit.aspx|publisher=accsc.org|title=Transfer of Credit |accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> The position of the [[American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers]] (AACRAO) was that national accrediting standards were not as rigorous and, though they might be well-suited for vocational and career education, were ill-suited for academic institutions.<ref name="aacrao">{{cite web|url=http://www.aacrao.org/federal_relations/transfer/FEDERALIZING_TRANSFER_OF_ACADEMIC_CREDIT.pdf |title=''Federalized Transfer of Academic Credit, Proposed Mandate Would Hurt Students'' AACRAO website |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226201419/http://www.aacrao.org/federal_relations/transfer/FEDERALIZING_TRANSFER_OF_ACADEMIC_CREDIT.pdf |archivedate=26 December 2010 }}</ref> AACRAO alleged that this proposed rule was unnecessary and unjustified, could threaten the autonomy and potentially lower the standards of regionally accredited schools, and drive up their costs.<ref name=aacrao/> Furthermore, it stated the proposed rule was an attempt by the for-profits' "well-funded lobbyists" to obscure the difference between for-profits' "lax academic criteria for accreditation" and non-profits' higher standards.<ref name=aacrao/>
Some for-profit schools have received regional accreditation, including [[American InterContinental University]], [[American Public University System]], [[Capella University]], [[DeVry University]], [[Kaplan University]], [[National American University]], [[Post University]], [[San Joaquin Valley College]], [[Strayer University]], [[University of Phoenix]], [[Universal Technical Institute]], and [[Walden University]].
Accrediting agencies have gained some scrutiny and criticism for conflicts of interest. Because these agencies receive their funding from the institutions themselves, they may have a vested interest in not aggressively supervising these for-profit colleges.<ref name="huffingtonpost.com1">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/19/for-profit-college-accreditation_n_3937079.html|title=How For-Profit Colleges Stay In Business Despite Terrible Track Record|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=14 June 2015|date=19 September 2013}}</ref>
According to Chris Kirkham and Kevin Short: "Two accrediting bodies...collectively monitor nearly 60 percent of all American for-profit colleges. They preside over almost half of those schools with the nation's worst student loan default rates....Ten of the 15 board members supervising the ACICS are drawn from the industry, including executives from Corinthian, [[Education Corporation of America]] and [[ITT Technical Institute]]. On the ACCSC board, industry executives fill eight of the 13 slots, representing publicly traded companies such as [[Universal Technical Institute]] and [[Kaplan, Inc.|Kaplan]] Higher Education."<ref name="huffingtonpost.com1"/>
In 2016, 12 Attorneys General asked the [[US Department of Education]] to stop the renewal of [[ACICS]], the [[Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools]]<ref name="propublica">{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/attorneys-general-come-down-on-accreditor-of-for-profit-colleges|publisher=propublica.org|title=Attorneys General Come Down on Accreditor of For-profit Colleges - ProPublica|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref>
In June 2016, the Department of Education deliberated on the fate of [[ACICS]] and its power to accredit schools for Title IV government funds.<ref name="wsj2">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-for-profit-kill-zone-1466638683|publisher=wsj.com|title=The For-Profit Kill Zone - WSJ|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> On June 23, 2016, The National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity (NACIQI), voted to revoke ACICS's power to accredit schools.<ref name="dailycaller">{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2016/06/24/government-drops-a-bomb-on-for-profit-colleges/|publisher=dailycaller.com|title=Feds Drops A-Bomb On For-Profit Colleges | The Daily Caller|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref>
==Business failures== Notable failures include [[Corinthian Colleges]], [[ITT Technical Institute]], and [[Education Management Corporation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2014/06/26/corinthians-failure-and-us-role-it-fuels-profit-critics|title=Corinthian's failure (and U.S. role in it) fuels for-profit critics |publisher=Insidehighered.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/business/2014/08/27/EDMC-debt-restructuring/stories/201408270182|title=EDMC announces debt restructuring; expects improved capital structure|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|accessdate=14 June 2015|date=27 August 2014}}</ref> In 2010, [[Trump University]] was closed by the State of New York for operating without a license.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/16/us-trump-nyag-lawsuit-idUSKCN0I52MW20141016|title=New York judge finds Donald Trump liable for unlicensed school|work=Reuters|accessdate=14 June 2015|date=16 October 2014}}</ref> In 2014, FastTrain college closed after being raided by the FBI.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/miami/press-releases/2014/fast-train-owner-and-three-admissions-representatives-arrested-for-theft-of-federal-student-aid|title=FBI — Fast Train Owner and Three Admissions Representatives Arrested for Theft of Federal Student Aid|work=FBI|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> In 2016, all campuses of [[Westwood College]] closed.<ref name="insidehighered.com"/>
In 2016, the US Department of Education stripped [[ACICS]], the accreditor of ITT Tech and many more colleges, of its accrediting power.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} The ACICS was given the power back under Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/editorials/la-ed-devos-student-loans-20180831-story.html|title=Betsy DeVos sides with predatory for-profit colleges over America's students}}</ref>
==Government scrutiny, criminal and civil investigations==
According to A.J. Angulo, for-profit higher education in the US has been the subject of government scrutiny from the mid-1980s to the 2010s.<ref name="books.google.com"/>
For-profits topped the Department of Education's list for the 2005–2007 cohort default rates, with campuses at ATI and Kaplan reporting default rates far above 20%. Most of the for-profits' expansion has been in the states of California, Arizona, Texas and Florida, with the metro areas of Los Angeles, Phoenix, Dallas and Miami-[[West Palm Beach]] being centers of their growth.<ref name="bloomberg.com"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Vasquez|first=Michael|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2010/09/04/1809205/for-profit-schools-grow-as-do.html|title=For-profit schools grow – as do complaints – Education|work=Miami Herald|date=2011-03-15|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/05/us/05fraud.html|work=The New York Times|title=School Is Linked To Visa Fraud|first=Carmen|last=Gentile|date=March 4, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ramsey|first=Ross|url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-education/higher-education/private-for-profit-colleges-under-the-microscope/|title=Private, For-Profit Colleges Under the Microscope – Higher Education|publisher=The Texas Tribune|date=2010-07-20|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://californiawatch.org/watchblog/whistleblower-lawsuit-against-profit-education-company-unsealed|title=Whistleblower lawsuit against for-profit education company unsealed|publisher=California Watch|date=May 10, 2010|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> For comparison, in Miami, [[Everest Institute]] reports a default rate for two of its campuses to be 18% and 20%; [[Miami Dade College]], the district's community college, which serves as a primary channel for local beginning students, reports a default rate of roughly 10%; [[Florida International University]], a public university serving the Miami metropolitan area, reports approximately 5%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/offices/OSFAP/defaultmanagement/peps300.zip |format=ZIP |title=FY11 Official 300 Report |publisher=2.ed.gov |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
In August 2010, the [[Government Accountability Office]] reported on an investigation that randomly sampled student-recruiting practices of several for-profit institutions. Investigators who posed as prospective students documented deceptive recruiting practices, including misleading information about costs and potential future earnings. They also reported that some recruiters had urged them to provide false information on applications for financial aid.<ref>Daniel de Vise and Paul Kane, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/04/AR2010080403816.html GAO: 15 for-profit colleges used deceptive recruiting tactics], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', August 5, 2010</ref> Out of the fifteen sampled, all were found to have engaged in deceptive practices, improperly promising unrealistically high pay for graduating students, and four engaged in outright [[fraud]], per a GAO report released at a hearing of the [[Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee]] held on August 4, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-10-948T|title=U.S. GAO - For-Profit Colleges: Undercover Testing Finds Colleges Encouraged Fraud and Engaged in Deceptive and Questionable Marketing Practices|publisher=Gao.gov|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> Examples of misconduct include: * offering [[commission (remuneration)|commissions]] to admissions officers, * employing deceptive marketing tactics by refusing to disclose total tuition cost to prospective students before signing a binding agreement, * lying about accreditation, * encouraging outright fraud by enticing students to take out student loans even when the applicant had $250,000 in savings, * promising extravagant, unlikely high pay to students, * failing to disclose graduation rate, and * offering tuition cost equivalent to 9 months of credit hours per year, when total program length was 12 months. The four for-profit colleges found to be engaging in fraudulent practices were: # Westech, California: Encouraging [[undercover]] applicant with falsified $250,000 in savings to falsely increase the number of dependents in the household in order to qualify for a Pell Grant, as well as take out the maximum amount in student loans; # [[Medvance Institute]] in [[Miami, Florida]]: Financial aid representative told an applicant not to report $250,000 in savings, comparing student loans to a car payment in that, "no one will come after you if you don't pay". In fact, a student loan default may remain in the debtor's credit history, prevent them from taking out a car loan, mortgage or rent, and may have their pay garnished up to 15%, until the student loan is paid in full.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} Another admissions officer at Kaplan College in Pembroke Pines, Florida,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2010-08-05/news/fl-kaplan-for-profit-investigation-20100805_1_kaplan-college-for-profit-enrollment|title=Kaplan College suspends admissions at Pembroke Pines campus following federal investigation|work=Sun-Sentinel|date=2010-08-05|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> alluded to fraudulent behaviour stating to the applicant when inquiring about the repayment of loans, "You gotta look at it ... I owe $85,000 to the University of Florida. Will I pay it back? Probably not ... I look at life as tomorrows never promised ... Education is an investment, you’re going to get paid back ten-fold, no matter what."; # [[Anthem Institute]] in [[Springfield Township, Delaware County, Pennsylvania|Springfield, Pennsylvania]]: Financial aid representative editing applicant's FAFSA form by omitting $250,000 in savings; # [[Westwood College]] in [[Dallas, Texas]]: Admissions representative telling applicant to falsely add dependents to qualify for Pell Grants, assuring the applicant that the dependents would not be verified through previous income tax returns nor Social Security numbers, and financial aid representative encouraging applicant not to report the $250,000 in savings, stating that "it was not the government's business how much money the undercover applicant had in a bank account.", when the Department of Education requires students to report such assets, along with income, to determine how much and what type of financial aid will be awarded.{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} It was found that 14 out of 15 times, the tuition at a for-profit sample was more expensive than its public counterpart, and 11 out of 15 times, it was more expensive than the private counterpart. Examples of the disparity in full tuition per program include: $14,000 for a certificate at the for-profit institution, when the same diploma cost $500 at a public college; $38,000 for an Associate's at the for-profit institution, when the comparable program at the public college cost $5,000; $61,000 for a Bachelor's at the for-profit institution, compared to $36,000 for the same degree at the public college.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d10948t.pdf|title=GAO-10-948T For-Profit Colleges: Undercover Testing Finds Colleges Encouraged Fraud and Engaged in Deceptive and Questionable Marketing Practices|format=PDF|date=August 4, 2010|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> This is counter to [[International Education Corporation]] CEO [[Fardad Fateri|Fardad Fateri's]] claims of the lack of use of unorthodox recruiting practices and a for-profit's "value" in an IEC open letter to Congress,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iecglobal.com/Aug2710.asp |title=International Education Corporation : Newsroom |publisher=Iecglobal.com |date=2010-08-27 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} the tuition cost of certificates and associate degrees being 28 and 6 times more than at a public college, respectively; Fateri writes, "Credit should be given to non-profit universities that have been able to convince students and their sophisticated parents to pay approximately $400,000.00 for an undergraduate degree that will seldom lead to an academically related career." However, the most expensive college in the United States, [[Sarah Lawrence College]] in [[Bronxville, New York]], had a tuition cost of $41,040 for 2009 fiscal year,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/33380153/?slide=11|title=Most Expensive Colleges|work=[[CNBC]]|date=2009-10-19|accessdate=19 March 2011}}<!-- link says $54,410, not $41,040--></ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campusgrotto.com/most-expensive-colleges-for-2009-2010.html|title=Most Expensive Colleges for 2009–2010|publisher=CampusGrotto|date=2009-10-19|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> bringing the tuition of a four-year bachelor's degree to just above $160,000.
The institutions identified in the Committee hearing in respect to the GAO report numeration were: [[File:GAO 8.4.2010 for profit figures.png|thumb|right|500px|Tuition cost comparison between for-profit, public and private colleges for equivalent programs.]]
# [[University of Phoenix]] – [[Phoenix, Arizona]]<ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite news|last=Lauerman|first=John|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-08-04/for-profit-colleges-boiler-room-recruiting-described-at-senate-hearing.html|title=For-Profit Colleges Misled Students, Witnesses Say|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2010-08-04|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> # Everest Institute – [[Mesa, Arizona]]<ref name="Bloomberg August 4, 2010 article">Bloomberg August 4, 2010 article</ref> # Westech College – Victorville, Ontario, Moreno Valley, California<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/sbcounty/stories/PE_News_Local_D_college07.2cf999f.html|title=Two local colleges on list of deceptive schools|author=Mark Muckenfuss|work=The Press-Enterprise|date=August 6, 2010}}</ref> # [[Kaplan, Inc.|Kaplan]] – [[Riverside, California]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.familysecuritymatters.org/publications/id.7040/pub_detail.asp|title=Post Has Watergate Scandal of Its Own|author=Cliff Kincaid|publisher=Family Security Matters|date=August 13, 2010}}</ref> # [[Potomac College]] – Washington, D.C. # [[Bennett Career Institute]] – Washington, D.C. # Kaplan – [[Pembroke Pines, Florida]]<ref>''Sun-Sentinel'', August 5, 2010, local article</ref> # [[College of Office Technology]] – [[Chicago, Illinois]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cot.edu/ |title=There is only one main campus in Illinois, in Chicago |publisher=Cot.edu |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202181948/http://www.cot.edu/ |archivedate=2 February 2011 }}</ref> # [[Argosy University]] – [[Chicago, Illinois]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Jennifer Epstein|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2010/08/09/forprofit|title=News: Has the Conversation Changed?|publisher=Inside Higher Ed|date=2011-03-14|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> # University of Phoenix – [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]<ref name="Bloomberg August 4, 2010 article"/> # [[Anthem Institute]] – Springfield, Pennsylvania<ref name="ReferenceA">The Quick and the ED August 4, 2010 article</ref> # [[Westwood College]] – [[Dallas, Texas]]<ref name="ReferenceA"/> # Everest Institute – [[Dallas, Texas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liquida.com/page/9509207/|title=Blogs on: GAO targets Dallas schools in report on deceptive marketing|publisher=Liquida.com|accessdate=19 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120903181522/http://www.liquida.com/page/9509207/|archivedate=3 September 2012|df=}}</ref> # [[ATI Career Training]] – [[Dallas, Texas]]<ref>Liquida August 4, 2010 article</ref>
In 2010, students at for-profit institutions represented about 12% of all college students, but receive roughly 25% of all Federal Pell Grants and loans. They were also responsible for approximately 44% of all student loan defaults.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://projectonstudentdebt.org/files/pub/CDR_2014_NR.pdf |format=PDF |title=Despite Lower Rates, More Than 650,000 Defaulted on Federal Student Loans For-Profit Colleges Account for Nearly Half of all Defaults |publisher=Projectonstudentdebt.org |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/news_room_detail.aspx?id=56473|title=New Default Rate Data for Federal Student Loans: 44% of Defaulters Attended For-Profit Institutions|publisher=Pew Charitable Trusts|date=December 15, 2009|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> University of Phoenix topped this list with Pell Grant revenue of $656.9 million with second and third place held by Everest Colleges at $256.6 million and Kaplan College at $202.1 million for the 2008–2009 fiscal year, respectively.<ref name="Chronicle of Higher Education">[http://chronicle.com/article/Data-Points-For-Profit/63388 For-Profit Colleges Capitalize on Pell Grant Revenue], ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'', January 4, 2010.</ref> In 2003, a [[Government Accountability Office]] report estimated that overpayments of Pell Grants were running at about 3% annually, amounting to around $300 million per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d03821.pdf|title=TAXPAYER INFORMATION: Increased Sharing and Verifying of Information Could Improve Education's Award Decisions|date=July 2003|publisher=[[Government Accountability Office]]}}</ref> Some of the universities that were top recipients of Pell Grants had low graduation rates, leaving students degreeless, and many graduating alumni found it excessively difficult to find gainful employment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/06/degreed-and-jobless-for-p_n_673053.html|title=Degreed And Jobless, For-Profit College Graduate Turns To Stripping|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com|date=2010-08-06|accessdate=19 March 2011|first=Leah|last=Finnegan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/295688|title=Stripper says for-profit college degree 'worthless'|publisher=Digitaljournal.com|date=August 8, 2010|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> with their degrees, leading some former students to accuse recruiters of being "duplicitous", and bringing into serious question the effectiveness of awarding Pell Grants and other [[Title IV]] funds to for-profit colleges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-05-05/for-profit-n-j-college-halts-recruiting-of-homeless-update1-.html|title=For-Profit N.J. College Halts Recruiting of Homeless (Update1)|publisher=Businessweek|date=2010-05-05|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="Higher Ed Watch">[http://higheredwatch.newamerica.net/blogs/2007/02/u_of_phoenix Fed Up at the University of Phoenix], ''Higher Ed Watch'', February 27, 2007.</ref> University of Phoenix's graduation rate is 15%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.phoenix.edu/content/dam/altcloud/doc/about_uopx/University-of-Phoenix-Consumer-Information-Guide-2009-2010.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821102056/http://www.phoenix.edu/content/dam/altcloud/doc/about_uopx/University-of-Phoenix-Consumer-Information-Guide-2009-2010.pdf |archivedate=21 August 2010 |df= }} (dead link: {{cite web|url=http://www.phoenix.edu/content/dam/altcloud/doc/about_uopx/University-of-Phoenix-Consumer-Information-Guide-2009-2010.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821102056/http://www.phoenix.edu:80/content/dam/altcloud/doc/about_uopx/University-of-Phoenix-Consumer-Information-Guide-2009-2010.pdf |archivedate=21 August 2010 |df= }}, archived August 21, 2010)</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/11/education/11phoenix.html|work=The New York Times|title=Troubles Grow for a University Built on Profits|first=Sam|last=Dillon|date=February 11, 2007}}</ref> [[Strayer University]], which reports its loan repayment rate to be 55%, only has a repayment rate of roughly 25%,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archival.malformedxmlelement.com/For-Profit%20Colleges/Strayer%20ge-cumulative-rates.xls |title=Archived copy |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811171948/http://archival.malformedxmlelement.com/For-Profit%20Colleges/Strayer%20ge-cumulative-rates.xls |archivedate=11 August 2011 |df= }} (dead link: {{cite web|url=http://archival.malformedxmlelement.com/For-Profit%20Colleges/Strayer%20ge-cumulative-rates.xls |title=Archived copy |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811171948/http://archival.malformedxmlelement.com/For-Profit%20Colleges/Strayer%20ge-cumulative-rates.xls |archivedate=11 August 2011 |df= }}. Archived: August 11, 2011)</ref> according to data released by the [[U.S. Department of Education]] on August 13, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/policy/highered/reg/hearulemaking/2009/ge-cumulative-rates.xls |format=XLS |title=Cumulative Rates |publisher=2.ed.gov |accessdate=4 July 2015}} </ref> The low repayment rate made [[Strayer]] ineligible for receiving further Title IV funds in accordance with new "Gainful employment" regulations brought forth by the Department of Education, which were to take effect in July 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/content/download/357892/4393975/file/Gainful%20Employment%20NPRM.pdf |title=gainful employment NPRM |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101105052245/http://www.insidehighered.com/content/download/357892/4393975/file/Gainful%20Employment%20NPRM.pdf |archivedate=5 November 2010 }}</ref> If passed, the minimum loan repayment requirement for any institution receiving Title IV funds, subject to suspension and expulsion if not compliant, will be 45%.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/14/education/14college.html|work=The New York Times|title=Data Show Low Loan Repayment at For-Profit Schools|first=Tamar|last=Lewin|date=August 13, 2010}}</ref>
In an August 4, 2010 Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee hearing, Gregory Kutz of the [[GAO]] stated that the fraudulent practices may be widespread in the For-Profit industry, noting a University of Phoenix executive chart that encouraged deceptive practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/294901-1|title=For-Profit College Financial Aid, Government Panel|publisher=C-SPAN|date=2010-08-04|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> Joshua Pruyn, a former admissions representative, disclosed to the committee hearing several internal emails distributed among admissions officers in March 2008 which encouraged applications and enrollments through the use of a commissions reward system. During a congressional hearing to present the report, Pruyn's testimony was disproven by tapes of conversations, and it was reported that Pruyn's comments were written by attorneys who were suing Westwood,<ref>{{cite news|last=Strong|first=Jonathan|title=Reporter|url=http://dailycaller.com/2011/08/04/star-harkin-witness-testimony-under-fire/|accessdate=4 August 2011|newspaper=The Daily Caller|date=2011-08-04}}</ref> and inappropriately coached by Chairman of the committee Senator [[Thomas Harkin]] staffers who organized the hearing.<ref name=07-21-2011>{{cite news|last=Strong|first=Jonathan|title=Dem Senator Accused of Witness Tampering|url=http://nation.foxnews.com/tom-harkin/2011/07/21/dem-senator-accused-witness-tampering|date=2011-07-21|newspaper=Fox News|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> Sen. Harkin noted the [[conflict of interest]] due to the ACCSC, a national accrediting agency that accredits many for-profit colleges nationwide,<ref name="accsc">{{cite web|url=http://www.accsc.org/Content/CommissionActions/documents/STBCListAugust2010.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917065411/http://accsc.org/Content/CommissionActions/documents/STBCListAugust2010.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 September 2010 |publisher=accsc.org|title=404 |accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref> receiving compensation directly from the institutions to which it awards accreditation. The [[Inspector General]] issued an assessment in late 2009 recommending the limiting and possible suspension or expulsion of the [[Higher Learning Commission]] of the [[North Central Association of Colleges and Schools]] due to conflicts in the manner in which the accrediting agency reviews credit hours and program length for online-colleges, specifically [[American InterContinental University]], a for-profit college.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lloyd|first=Marion|url=http://chronicle.com/article/Inspector-Generals-Warning-to/63206/|title=Inspector General's Warning to Accreditor Raises Fears Among For-Profit Institutions|publisher=Chronicle of Higher Education|date=2009-12-17|accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> The NCA HLC accredits the [[University of Phoenix]] and Everest in Phoenix, Arizona.
On November 30, 2010, the GAO issued a revised report, softening several examples from an undercover investigation and changing some key passages, but stood by its central finding that colleges had encouraged fraud and misled potential applicants.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/07/AR2010120706803.html|title=GAO revises its report critical of practices at for-profit schools|work=The Washington Post|first=Nick|last=Anderson|date=2010-12-08}}</ref>
In 2014, a criminal investigation of [[Corinthian Colleges]] was initiated.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-corinthian-colleges-20140814-story.html|title=Corinthian Colleges tells investors it is facing a criminal probe|author=Los Angeles Times|date=13 August 2014|work=latimes.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
Until 2015, The US Attorney General and at least eleven states maintained an $11 billion lawsuit against [[Education Management Corporation]] <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/city/2014/05/06/Judge-says-lawsuit-against-Education-Management-can-continue/stories/201405060222|title=Judge says lawsuit against Education Management can continue|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|accessdate=14 June 2015|date=6 May 2014}}</ref> The US [[Consumer Financial Protection Bureau]] also has a suit against ITT Educational Services, parent company of [[ITT Tech]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.republicreport.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/cfpb_complaint_ITT.pdf |format=PDF |title=Consumer Financial Protection Bureau v. ITT Educational Services, Inc. |publisher=Republicreport.org |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.consumerfinance.gov/newsroom/cfpb-sues-for-profit-college-chain-itt-for-predatory-lending/|title=CFPB Sues For-Profit College Chain ITT For Predatory Lending|work=Consumer Financial Protection Bureau|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> In 2016, Alejandro Amor, the founder of FastTrain, was sentenced to eight years in federal prison for fraud.<ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/ed/2016/05/12/477655591/jail-time-for-a-for-profit-college-founder|publisher=npr.org|title=As Feds Crack Down On For-Profit College, A Founder Heads To Prison For Fraud : NPR Ed : NPR|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref>
==Attempts to regulate and deregulate the industry== The [[US Department of Education]] (DoED) has proposed rules, "gainful employment regulations", that would provide more transparency and accountability to institutions that offer professional and technical training. According to DoED, this regulation is an attempt to "protect borrowers and taxpayers."<ref>{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Obama Administration Announces Final Rules to Protect Students from Poor-Performing Career College Programs |url= http://www.ed.gov/news/press-releases/obama-administration-announces-final-rules-protect-students-poor-performing-care|location= |publisher= [[United States Department of Education]] |agency= |date= October 30, 2014 |accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref>
In his 2015 budget proposal, President Obama recommended greater regulation of for-profit education, including a closure of the loophole that exempted GI Bill money from being used in the 90-10 formula.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2015/02/03/obama-seeks-boost-higher-education-spending-and-proposes-some-loan-reforms-have|title=Obama seeks to boost higher education spending and proposes some loan reforms that have bipartisan appeal - InsideHigherEd|publisher=Insidehighered.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2017, the US Department of Education held public hearings were held in order to determine whether the government had overstepped regulation efforts, particularly with [[gainful employment]] and [[defense to repayment]] rules.<ref>https://www.usnews.com/news/education-news/articles/2017-07-10/trump-administration-begins-rewriting-for-profit-regulations</ref>
In August 2017, Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos instituted policies to loosen regulations on for-profit colleges.<ref name="consumerist.com"/>
In September 2017, the Trump Administration proposed to remove conflict of interest rules between VA officials and for-profit colleges.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/29/business/veterans-affairs-ethics.html|title=Veterans Agency Seeks to Scrap Ethics Law on For-Profit Colleges|first=Patricia|last=Cohen|date=September 29, 2017|publisher=|access-date=January 1, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
===For-profit college lobbyists promoting deregulation=== Lobbyists for the for-profit higher education industry have taken several steps to stop regulation and to fight against transparency and accountability.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/quicktakes/2014/11/07/profit-groups-sue-block-gainful-employment-rules|title=For-Profit Groups Sue to Block Gainful Employment Rules |publisher=Insidehighered.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> They have also supported at least two lawsuits to squash gainful employment regulations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.career.org/news-and-media/press-releases/upload/APSCU-v-Duncan-DDC-2014-11-06-Plaintiff-s-Complaint.pdf |format=PDF |title=Association of Private Sector Colleges and Universities v. Arne Duncan |publisher=Career.org |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/2014/11/07/for-profit-colleges-file-lawsuit-to-halt-new-obama-administration-regulations/|title=For-profit colleges file lawsuit to halt new Obama administration regulations|work=Fox Business|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apscu.org/news-and-media/press-releases/upload/APSCU-v-Duncan-DDC-2015-02-06-Plaintiff-s-Motion-for-Summary-Judgment2.pdf |format=PDF |title=Association of Private Sector Colleges and Universities v. Arne Duncan |publisher=Apscu.org |accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
==For-profit colleges transitioning to nonprofit colleges== At least three colleges or universities have transitioned to nonprofit status: [[Keiser University]], [[Remington College]], and [[Herzing University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/blogs/ticker/for-profit-herzing-u-converts-to-nonprofit-status/91695|title=For-Profit Herzing U. Converts to Nonprofit Status – The Ticker - Blogs - The Chronicle of Higher Education|publisher=Chronicle.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> Journalists argue that these transitions are strategies to reduce state and federal regulations and to obtain more [[Title IV]] funds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/davidhalperin/if-a-for-profit-college-b_b_2661788.html|title=If a For-Profit College Becomes a Non-Profit, Is That Good? Not Necessarily|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=14 June 2015|date=11 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/business/herzing-university-becomes-a-nonprofit-organization-b99419151z1-287365131.html|title=Herzing University becomes a nonprofit organization|author=Rick Romell|publisher=Jsonline.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2014 [[Grand Canyon University]] considered a transition to nonprofit status.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-13/grand-canyon-eyes-2-billion-exit-from-for-profit-college-stigma.html|title=Grand Canyon Eyes $2 Billion Exit From For-Profit College Stigma|author=Michael McDonald|date=13 November 2014|work=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> In March 2016, Grand Canyon's regional accreditation body, [[The Higher Learning Commission]], formally rejected the university's petition for conversion to non-profit status. The commission's board of directors stated that the school did not meet all five criteria for "such a conversion".<ref name="www.hlcommission.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.hlcommission.org/download/_PublicDisclosureNotices/Grand%20Canyon%20University%20PDN.pdf|title=Public Disclosure Notice|website=HLCommission.org|access-date=January 1, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ktar.com">{{cite web|url=http://ktar.com/story/946879/grand-canyon-university-denied-switch-to-nonprofit-status/|publisher=ktar.com|title=Grand Canyon University denied switch to nonprofit status|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref><ref name="www.abc15.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc15.com/news/region-phoenix-metro/central-phoenix/grand-canyon-university-denied-request-to-switch-to-nonprofit-status|publisher=abc15.com|title=Grand Canyon University denied request to switch to nonprofit status - ABC15 Arizona|accessdate=18 February 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Kaplan University]] was sold to [[Purdue University]] and became [[Purdue University Global]] in 2018. Kaplan, however would be the servicer for the institution and the Higher Learning Commission would continue to accredit the school. <ref>https://www.purdue.edu/newsroom/releases/2018/Q1/purdue-announces-name-for-new-public-university-purdue-university-global-to-serve-working-adults,-online.html</ref><ref>https://www.jconline.com/story/news/2018/09/10/regulators-purdue-campus-review-purdue-global-deal/1252718002/</ref>
In 2018, [[Grand Canyon University]] and [[Ashford University]] petitioned for non-profit status.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2018/03/13/ashford-university-latest-big-profit-attempt-nonprofit-conversion|title=Ashford University is latest big for-profit to attempt nonprofit conversion|author=|date=|website=insidehighered.com}}</ref>
